DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Needy People Left Empty-Handed By Theft of Food Packages
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of needy people were turned away empty-handed from a community center after a real-life Grinch stole thousands of dollars worth of food, toys and clothing collected for a traditional Christmas Eve giveaway. Volunteer workers at the Paul Hall Community Services Center were distributing whatever food and toys were left by burglars who broke into a storage shed early Sunday morning, said Willie Hall, director of the center. ``We did distribute about 400 food baskets today, but we had to turn away about 300-400 people this afternoon,'' Hall said. ``People were very distressed, but they did understand the problems. We assured them we are doing the best we can to try to get some food to accommodate them.'' The center also had planned to distribute toys to about 1,000 children Christmas Eve, but there were only enough toys left for 500 children, Hall said. Frank Campbell, a spokesman for the center, said the theft disappointed many of the needy _ some of whom had been waiting in freezing temperatures as early as 7 a.m. for the afternoon distribution. ``Some Grinch came in and stole Christmas for these kids,'' Campbell said. ``Our main goal was to supply a nice meal for people who are poor and homeless throughout the city.'' The thieves also stole train sets, remote-controlled cars and other toys donated by local businesses, Hall said. The burglars must have been prepared for the theft, Campbell said, because in four hours they stole several hundred 10-pound turkeys, hams and chickens as well as several hundred toys. Campbell said he didn't know the exact value of the items taken because most were donated, but estimated at least $3,000 worth of property had been taken. As news about the theft spread, hundreds of people came to the South Side center throughout the afternoon and evening to donate hams, turkeys and canned goods, Hall said. He said organizers planned to distribute food baskets today to those who were turned away. ``The theft did kill the Christmas spirit earlier, but people have come throughout the day to show the Christmas spirit,'' Hall said. ``Hundreds of people in the Chicago area have come ... to help us out in our plight.'' Police were working to find the culprit or culprits, said Officer John Crotty. ``We're not looking for anything from these (burglars),'' Campbell said. ``What we would like is whoever broke in today to bring the food back.'' The community center, originally called the Paul Hall Boys Club, was founded in the 1960s by the Rev. Paul J. Hall, who gained national attention for his efforts to help poor youngsters and their families through such projects as Christmas food giveaways.
